physical_appearance:The image shows a display stand. It  is brown in colour. The top of the display stand has a flat upper surface. It is of a lighter shade of brown as compared to its base. The base of the display stand is carved to resemble intertwining roots. The roots are gnarled in appearance. The root formation closest to the foreground of the image extends outwards
 as compared to the others which tend to be clustered.
subject_terms_1:carvings (visual works) symbolism (artistic concept) cultural artefacts

subject_terms_3:Artefacts
sgcool_label_text:This huangyangmu (boxwood) stand has been carved
 at least partially
 to appear like a natural root formation. It consists of a flat upper surface supported by gnarled
 intertwining roots. The Chinese literati favoured furnishings that alluded to nature in form as well as materiality. Made of wood or stone
 these items which included tables
 stools and stands were also often depicted in Ming and Qing paintings.

metadata.physical_appearance: The image shows a display stand. It  is brown in colour. The top of the display stand has a flat upper surface. It is of a lighter shade of brown as compared to its base. The base of the display stand is carved to resemble intertwining roots. The roots are gnarled in appearance. The root formation closest to the foreground of the image extends outwards, as compared to the others which tend to be clustered.
metadata.subject_terms_1: carvings (visual works) symbolism (artistic concept) cultural artefacts
metadata.sgcool_label_text: This huangyangmu (boxwood) stand has been carved, at least partially, to appear like a natural root formation. It consists of a flat upper surface supported by gnarled, intertwining roots. The Chinese literati favoured furnishings that alluded to nature in form as well as materiality. Made of wood or stone, these items which included tables, stools and stands were also often depicted in Ming and Qing paintings.
